I haven't read all the posts, so perhaps this has been mentioned, but isn't this analogous of the 'slit' type camera shutters of the pre-60's? Up to +/- 1/30 sec. the shutter would expose the whole film frame. Faster than that speed, (1/60, 1/125, 1/250 etc.....) the second shutter blind would move across the frame exposing just a narrow segment of the film at at time. This is why, photos taken in the early 1900's, showed fast moving vehicles with oval wheels.
Cameras dont do this anymore so this video is very outdated.

A classic example of an early effect like this, is Jacques Henri Lartigue's 1913 photo of the #6 race car, beautifully distorted by the panning motion of the camera, and a horizontal leaf spring shutter, making the entire car "lean forward" in the direction it moved, with oval wheels, and the people on the background leaning on the opposite angle, as if they had been "blown back" by the car's turbulence. This effect is clearly understood once we realize the shutter first opened from top to bottom, and the upper leaf closed from top to bottom as well, as the camera rapidly panned right to accompany the 'fast moving car'. Lartigue was still a child when he produced this image,  which still fascinates us almost 110 years later,  and I cannot imagine his awe when seeing the negative,  immediately after processing it!

The propeller blades appear to be stationary in the same position. This is not a magic trick by some well-known illusionist. Only camera enthusiasts know the trick. This type of optical effect, in fact, is obtained when the 'frame rate' of the camera, or the frequency of the frames with which it is shooting, is synchronized with the rotation speed of the object being shot.

Ok... so why don't they use rolling line with the same shutter speed when replaying the video? Then it should replay the original image.
And... why don't they design the camera chips so that all the pixels take a snapshot at the same time? Rolling shutters were needed in the age of the mechanical camera, because it was the only practical way to make short shutter speeds. I don't see why they are needed on camera chips.

So when looking at a spinning object with a camera, the direction of compression, could be thought of as the cross product between the unit vectors of the velocity of the rolling shutter, and the angular momentum of the spinning object.

Every generation of video recording has had different forms of distortion, from the jittery motion of film shot at 16fps in the early 20th century, sometimes made worse if replayed at 24fps, to the strange colours when colour film first came out, the vertical scratches and flickering dust from film projectors, the horizontal effects seen on video-tape, the very poor pixel size when cheap video cameras first came out... And that is before you even get to the effects that you get on TV, such as hue variation and moiré (which varied enormously from country to country).

And throughout it all, the wagon-wheel lives on.

Which is why there is no such thing as real time.  All things have delays in processing a continuous moving image.  During the delay for processing no more data is being processed from the sensor (eye or CCD for that matter).  The data can be stored (if the storage process is fast enough) and analyzed later (sometimes within microseconds).  Great video!

It's a phenomenon called "Time Parallax". Time parallax happens in movie cameras, camera with a slit shutter like "focal plane" or "curtain shutter" (that could be mounted in front of the lens before WW2). And in all scanning electronic cameras like TV cameras or digital cameras. A flashing lightsource like fluorescent light can cause banding in cameras with a time parallax shutter, because different moments of exposure have light on or off and these different moments relate to different sections of the film or sensor.

As a pro sports photographer, and engineer, I’ve gotten into these discussions with fellow shooters when looking at photos of things like baseball bats being swung, pitcher’s arms, etc.. These things DO curve and bend, but the rolling shutter distorts what is actually occurring, sometimes minimizing the actual curvature, and sometimes exacerbating it. This can be shown when using the same camera, in the same orientation, shooting left handed batter vs right handed batters, from the front side of the batters.  Again, well done!

Great video, but can I just offer a slight correction? The sensor is scanned from top to bottom, but because the lens inverts the image onto the sensor, it's actually recording the image from bottom to top. Hence the bridge you showed at 1:18 is leaning towards the left which is the direction you were travelling in. So the top of the image was recorded later than the bottom, making it lean to the left.

Most 35mm film cameras had a similar shutter that exposes the film in a slit that moves side to side (a few cameras have shutters that go top to bottom or visa versa).  The 35mm shutters actually do open completely and stay open for the duration of the exposure AT SLOW SHUTTER SPEEDS.  Above a certain speed they revert to the moving slit mode.

Don't know how to tell you this, but a film camera doesn't expose the whole film during the same time either.  It approaches that "ideal" for long exposures, but, as I remember, most 35mm SLRs had a 1/125 second maximum shutter speed with flash.  This was because at faster exposures than that, the entire film surface was NEVER exposed during the shot.  At 1/1000 second exposure times the actual area exposed was just a traveling slit about 1/8th, give or take,  of the entire film area as a moving slit, with the light blocking part of the shutter following the light allowing part pretty closely behind, starting to move LONG before the opening shutter hit it's far stop.  Since you were really just allowing the majority of the light in from the flash (dark photography),  you would have just exposed the slit part that was open during the flash, which is short by comparison, and not the entire area of the film.  In essence, the flash duration was the "useful" exposure time.

To be fair, not all CMOS sensors use "rolling shutter" and the term itself is a bit of a misnomer here as the sensor is always completely exposed, but the individual bits of the sensor are being polled in progressive scan. Some will instead cache the current exposure over a user-controlled number of milliseconds (shutter speed) in its entirety to some internal memory typically fused directly behind the sensor with an interposer. This feature is more common on DSLR cameras, but a small few phone cameras have the feature too. Can't remember which ones, but I know they exist.

You can count the frequency of the guitar strings using the rolling shutter! Given that you shot 30fps, it means each frame has span of 1/30s. At 4:08 you can count 7 waves on one of the strings. I remember as a child simulating these effects using a CRT television set to static and a gyroscope or anything else you could spin which let light through. I would hold up the gyroscope so I was looking through the center wheel thing and set it to spin. As we know, like the CMOS in the camera, the TV is interlaced and effectively "writes" a line a time on the TV. This is what gives it that "flicker" if you happen to film it.

But the gyroscope acted in the same way. The spokes would appear bent, curved or in some cases disappear completely as it spun down. I figured it had something to do with the flickering of the TV and the interlace letting me see bits of the wheel at different points but my brain in effect stitching them together to get a complete picture.

One way to look at these images is as skewed 3-dimensional cross sections of 4-dimensional objects. The plane with the moving propeller exists in 3 dimensions and a 4th dimension of time. The way we perceive time can be though of as a series of 3d cross sections - and those cross sections are always at the same angle.  What the rolling shutter does for us is skew that cross section in the time dimension.  If you take a 2d cross section of a cube, you will get a square, but if you skew it, you may end up with a rectangle, or a triangle, or even a hexagon.  The shape of the cross section looks less and less like the object it projects the more you skew it.  Similarly, when you take a skewed 3d cross section of a fast-spinning propeller, it starts to bend and even fragment.  One may look at the image of the fragments and ask how is that possible - the fragments are not connected to the hub? But they are connected - through a dimension that is outside of the cross section represented in the image.

Here is something cool and (somewhat) similar you can do easily at home:

Take a fidget spinner and view it being spun under different light sources such as LED, incandescent, fluorescent and natural light. These all have different frequencies the light is flickering at (short of natural light) which causes different visible patterns among the rotating fidget spinner.

Since vision is only light reflecting off of an object and being interpreted by our eyes, changing the light source, or differing frequencies, will create a different pattern on the fidget spinner (or other similarly moving objects).

If someone interested, AE effect what he was talking about is called Time Displacement
1. Make solid, add default Ramp effect, precompose with moving all attributes.
2. Add Time Displacement and set that precompose of ramp as map.
3. Change resolution of Displacement to height of your video (gonna render very long, but that's the best result, low this value if you wanna make faster render, 1/3 of height look pretty okay).
4. Waste a lot of time to render this on your potato.

@1:24, I'm fairly certain its a rolling shutter scanning down, IE from the top to the bottom of the frame. The top row of pixels are captured first at some initial position. As you go down the rows of pixels the camera moves leftward in the scene, and the background moves rightward relative to the initial position, and so all the following rows are captured with the appearance of having moved to the right of the initial row of pixels. It may have been better to have the green synchronisation guide at the top of the bollard rather than the bottom for some clarity for why this is the case.

On the guitar strings, the simulated image is a representation of the actual sound waveform w/ the fundamental & harmonics, albeit w/ low pass filtering & aliasing artifacts depending on scan rate. Pretty cool!

With a higher line scan rate, the still image of the strings would be very close to what you'd see if the string's isolated sound waveform were recorded on a DAQ or oscilloscope, albeit with low pass filtering due to hi-speed camera image resolution limitations that simply won't allow the low amplitude, high frequency harmonic components to be captured, unless you zoom WAY in.

How about that for a video? Compare the simulated image of an electric guitar string against what the pickup outputs. Do it at different scan rates to show what aliasing is vs the line-scan imaging artifacts this video is demonstrating.

An interesting slow motion rolling shutter effect would be a view of someone doing a 12th fret harmonic on the low E, view from a shallow angle over the bridge. You'd have to have a very wide focus to get the two halves of vibration though.

Awesome video, with one caveat.  Although I have known about rolling shutter, this is the first time I have seen it side-by-side with cameras of two different speeds.  The caveat is that even your high speed camera is subject to rolling shutter since the display is converted to an image by sweeping a beam across the camera tube, and therefore the display is also a fiction.  I suspect that you could make a video of the high speed camera rolling shutter if you have two high speed cameras running at different speeds (one camera at 24k fps and the other camera at 100k+ fps). In days before digital imaging the camera of choice was an SLR (without the D) with a focal plane curtain shutter. At certain shutter speeds it behaved somewhat as a rolling shutter. The shutter consisted of overlapping panels, with one panel opening the aperture followed by the second panel closing it by moving in the same direction. For very short exposures this would form a slit passing across the focal plane just above the film itself.
For film, with its always low ISO numbers it seldom had any effect, as the first shutter would completely open before the second began to close. Holding the camera steady was the problem and the propellers you show would just disappear in blur of motion for a properly photographed image. That rolling shutter has a great deal to do with modern digital imaging systems ability to at least be sharp enough to suit average users despite the occasionally odd shapes of fast moving objects within the frame.

Rolling shutter isn't unique to cheap digital cameras. Some large format film cameras with certain kinds of focal plane shutters also experience it. That's why if you look at old pictures of race cars in the 1920's the wheels look oval when driving. It's also why cartoonists drew wheels on moving cars oval instead of circular, to replicate the photos.

With regard to the vibrating guitar strings, I was able to accomplish the same thing WITHOUT a high-speed camera, but with my television (because the TV has/is a rolling DISPLAY, i.e. the image on the TV is a series of lines displaying one after the other at rapid speed).

I held up my guitar so that the strings were between my eye-line and the TV set, so when I plucked them, I could see the "rolling shutter" effect in real-time. You can see it vibrate at different speeds (frequencies?) when you fret the strings to change the pitch of the note.

One more interesting thing about rolling shutter that you could have included in your video is that you can actually tell certain RPM of a propeller (or any spinning object) using rolling shutter.  A 30 FPS cell phone camera, when head-on with a propeller, will show an image that appears like the propeller isn't moving when it's turning at 1800 RPM (also at 900 RPM) I've homebuilt my own aircraft and actually used this technique to help verify the accuracy of my tachometer.

Top to bottom left to right too. The Engineering Guy talks about how the pixels are trigged and in programming terms, 'popped' off the stack. In other words; the state of each pixel is read off, one by one and each state is passed to the next pixel in the row before it's finally read by the reader at the end. This is to prevent distortion caused by the super fine wires magnetically interfering with one another, the effect is so bad, not only can we only read one pixel at the time, but the signal from reading a pixel beside an existing pixel will cause the information on the adjacent pixel to be distorted, so instead, they just pass the signal, one on to the next.

Awesome video on the Rolling Shutter effect, however I wish you could have added more detail as to why you think that the rolling shutter effect and aliasing are different? It seems as though this effect is caused by spatial aliasing because you are sampling each "row" of pixels at a rate slower than the rate of your moving object (spinning or moving far above Nyquist) so with respect to each "row" it would appear aliased. Then staking all of those aliased rows up resulting in a video (or image) with the rolling shutter effect.

Shutter scanning direction: On DSLRs, the sensor scans top to bottom, but remember that when it comes through the lens the image is flipped, and is then flipped again in processing.
